title: When should grown ups help? the Vassar studies - studies of normal personality development
creator_contributor_role: Vassar College, Dept. of Child study, production company
subject_group: Education, Instruction, Teaching & Schools/Education of children
Food, Health, Lifestyle, Medicine, Psychology & Safety/Child psychology
Family, Gender Identity, Relationships & Sexuality/Child psychology
Family, Gender Identity, Relationships & Sexuality/Children and adults
Family, Gender Identity, Relationships & Sexuality/Education of children
Economics, Philosophy, Politics, Religion & Sociology/Education of children
description: Shows pre-school children in various situations, in some of which they require help from adults and in others manage successfully by themselves. Points out that sometimes help is necessary for the child to succeed in projects undertaken, and at other times it is important for adults not to impose their standards of speed or efficiency. Presents four scenes without comment, suggesting that the audience decide in which of these episodes the children should have been helped.
